    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for A2 learners in the CEFR scale.

     Police think burglars are most likely to hit houses during the afternoon, as families are out of the house at lunchtime.
    
    In January and February alone, 1,070 break-ins were recorded on the Eastbourne Borough Council area, a rise of 7% on the same period last year.
   
    Inspector Ian Saunders said: "During the afternoon, most burglaries are to detached houses with the owners usually out and about with the children.
   
    "During the day people tend to have their front doors and windows open and windows of nearby houses open as well."
   
    Mr Saunders told the Argus that thieves were looking for 'easy pickings', and would target houses in areas where there was nothing of value inside.
   
    He added that it was a common misconception that burglars were looking for gold coins and watches inside a house. He said: "They will be looking for wallets and purses, which can hold cash or cards with personal details that can be used to access houses and personal bank accounts."

     Every day Bill Prince-Smith writes. He puts the pen down at night, but in the office he scribbles away. In the morning he gives the work to his wife to read. If he'd read it himself he'd think it terrible—but his wife thinks the books are hilarious. It's the way he writes that makes them so funny. He writes by hand, using a pencil, then covers them over in blue ink. Sometimes his drawings appear in the book. But if it were illustrated by a professional it would all look too fancy—just too grown-up for the way his mind works. In the afternoon his wife reads the writing aloud. Then the manuscript is sent to the printer and becomes a paperback. By the time it hits the shelves, his audience has grown older and wiser, while his books have always remained the same age. So even when people are talking about things that were funny once, his books still are funny—they're always funny.
    Bill is sixty-three years old and he's still a farm boy. His father was a farmer, and he grew up on the farm just like his children do. Like his children, he was a teacher. He taught school for many years, and he also did some dentistry for a time. He went to dentist school after teaching, and now he's a dentist. Like his children, he had some failures and some successes, but the best part of his life has always been writing.

     Kong went back to Ann and took her down from the high rock. For the first time in this jungle she felt strangely safe. He jumped across a ravine and then across a river. She was a small plaything between his large fingers. Then he stopped and put her down.
    
    "Well," she said, "that makes two of us."
    
         Kong jumped to his feet and turned towards her.
    
    "How did you get here?" he asked.
    
         "You must've brought me to you," she said.
    
         Kong looked quizzically at Ann, "Why?"
    
         "Because," said Ann, "you look like my favorite cat."
    
         Kong looked even more quizzical.
    
          "You said so yourself," Ann said, "I have always loved cats."
    
         Kong's brow furrowed and he looked at Ann with a stare that seemed to stare right through her.

     The history of the London police begins in 1727, when King George I of England appointed the first municipal police constable, Thomas Bawdsey, to watch over his citizens. It is said that he had a reputation of being a hard-working man, and a keen tax collector.
In 1780, the Royal Assent was given to the "Act for the better regulation of the police in London", a set of laws that allowed the London police constabulary to be organised into ranks (of up to eight) and set hours of duty. The London police's work expanded from protecting the city's citizens to guarding public buildings in the 1780s. The same time period also saw the development of the force's first training school, as well as the formation of special units, such as the Special Patrol Unit (1812), the first of London's riot police.
During the nineteenth century, London's population more than doubled. By the end of the century, the police's budget had doubled, from £5 million to £10 million per year. The police took a more aggressive attitude towards crime, with the Metropolitan Police Act 1829 giving the police power to arrest and imprison "any person or persons committing or assisting in the committing of a crime, or otherwise obstructing justice, in any part of the said County".

     Little Cat Little Cat where have you been? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. She was discovered by the driver after he had completed a trip of more than 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day.
    Bo was really tired and wanted to go home, so she went back into the van to sleep. Luckily for Bo, when the driver went to get a drink of water, he accidentally put the door open and Bo snuck out! She had found the food that the driver left, and she was happy to share with the dog. They both felt quite lucky!
    Bo tried to find a safe place to sleep, but the van was really messy. She ended up on the table, under the blanket. She was quite cozy there, and she really relaxed. 
    After a few hours, she realised that the van driver had gone for a long walk with the dog and she had no food or water. She had to stay where she was for a few days and sleep near the door. One day, the driver came to check on her and was surprised that Bo was really friendly and wanted to stay with him. That night, the driver fell asleep and when he woke up, Bo was gone.
    Bo had tried to hide from the van driver, but eventually the driver spotted her and started to search for her, but she was gone.

     THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST

Hypatia was born in Alexandria in 370 A.D. For many centuries she was the only woman scientist to have a place in the history books. Hypatia's father was director of Alexandria University and he made sure his daughter had the best education available. This was unusual as most women then had few opportunities to study.

Hypatia was one of the few women of her time to attend classes in both philosophy and medicine. Her father allowed her to study these two disciplines at once so she could gain a more thorough understanding of medicine and philosophy. Hypatia was an extraordinary woman with much knowledge and insight.

She was interested in medicine as early as age five, when she was reading the works of Galen. When she was just 11 years old, she traveled to Athens where she studied medicine under Hippocrates. She returned to Alexandria and opened a clinic. This is where she spent the rest of her life.

Hypatia's death in 431 A.D. was an enormous loss to Egypt and Alexandria, but she did leave behind a collection of over 8,000 scrolls. Some of these writings are in Latin, which is spoken only by a small percentage of the world's population. The Latin language has preserved much of Hypatia's important message. 

Hypatia was also an accomplished orator. She gave more than 400 public speeches in her lifetime. She was a great teacher

     The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland and winter temperatures there can reach -40°C. But 6000 holidaymakers still go there annually to visit what is probably Europe's most unusual accommodation. In this hotel, you eat, drink and sleep in rooms made of ice. If you want, you can even get married in one.
    The Ice Hotel was built in 1995 and is open to tourists every winter. It has a bar, a restaurant, and five ice rooms, each measuring six by twelve metres and each consisting of three tonnes of ice set in concrete. A couple have a ceremony there, while others choose to celebrate their anniversary in the hotel's disco. But it is the hot tub that takes centre stage. The rooms are available as individual or group accommodation, and the prices start from 2,000 Swedish kronor (around £180).
    The owners of the hotel, Anders Sundström and his wife, Katarina, are also responsible for the hotel's famous ice bar, in the shape of a giant cube, and the bar's ice maze. The maze contains more than 1,300 different ice cubes. The maze is an experience in itself, but the bar is open until two in the morning. A typical cocktail costs around 20 kronor (around £1.40).
    Anders and Katarina started the hotel to give their three children a better experience of the holidays,

     San Francisco lies on the coast of northern California. The earliest Europeans to discover the area were led by a Spanish explorer whose name was Gaspar de Portola. He first saw it in 1769. Surprisingly, although San Francisco Bay is a wonderful natural harbour, it was discovered by land rather than by sea.
    In early October 1842, California became part of the United States. President James Buchanan visited the city of San Francisco as part of his trip across the Western United States in 1842, but it wasn't until 1850 that President William Henry Harrison actually set foot in the Golden State. Even then, his visit was cut short when he fell ill while visiting San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. 
    In 1888, the first transcontinental railroad was built through San Francisco. This opened up trade routes to the rest of the country and allowed the city to become one of the largest in the world. By the 20th century, San Francisco had become a megalopolis and the largest American city by land area.

     Money is a unit of exchange; in the most simple of definitions it can be defined as something that can be given in exchange for something else. When the definition gets slightly more nuanced than this, one usually has in mind things such as notes and coins, but the point is that in essence, money is something given in exchange for something else.
To clarify the difference between what is commonly called money and notes and coins, a pound (symbol: £) is roughly worth the same as a dollar or a franc (symbol: €), but £ is much less valuable than a hundred €. (In other words, €100 is worth nearly a thousand pounds.) Similarly, a book is worth more than a hundred dollars, while a handful of sweets are worth a few cents. The relative values of these items are not affected by their relative value in pounds (although they may be affected by the relative value of their contents).
The value of money has varied throughout history, but it has almost universally been a feature of economic activity. Early attempts to define and standardize money were usually unsuccessful, as this has led to all sorts of different currencies, most of them based on their perceived usefulness and usefulness as medium of exchange. A prime example of a currency whose value was never standardized is the penny; it was used throughout the United Kingdom until 1796 and in the rest of the world until 1971. The Skywalk is made out of steel cables and it weighs about 7000 tonnes. The Skywalk starts from the trail which passes over the canyon.      Advertising can target young children in ways that can have a profound impact on adults. In the TV adverts that we see, cartoon animals often do all the advertising and have their own separate TV programmes; the commercial advertising on the radio is often played to children, and the children’s television shows have children acting in them. If children can see and hear these adverts and programmes, and are able to understand them, the adverts can also influence their parents’ purchasing decisions.

These adverts are, therefore, targeted at children. For example, adverts for drinks can feature cartoon animals. In the TV adverts, it is the children who actually buy the drinks, not their parents. There is an interesting comparison with Jane Eyre, a novel that describes the influence of advertising and its effect on a young person, Charlotte Bronte. Her novel tells the story of a young, lonely governess, who becomes an active member of the society around her. Because the novel is about advertising, it also uses advertising as a source of information about the society. Bronte wanted her novel to be realistic, yet also give an insight into the society in which she lived, so that the reader felt as though he or she was experiencing society for the first time. The advertisements that she used in her book were carefully selected to tell a story that would not have been possible if she had used a different method of persuasion, such as using emotive words.

     As my father used to say:  ‘Gold in the gold rush!’ I was an eager student, desperate for the latest knowledge at a time of great change in my family's fortunes. I felt, as an only son in my mid-twenties, I should be doing something of significance to improve our lot in life. If I could find employment, I would not be too old to work with my father. On top of all that, I wanted to settle down and have a family. At that time, my father was an engineer on the railways, but no longer in the lucrative and well-paid role in which he had trained. For one thing, he was no longer in a seniority role, and another was his work was so demanding he could hardly spend time at home in his beloved Dublin city.
   
    His role at the railway was dangerous; there had been too many fatal accidents, so as he could not be blamed, and it was hard work to get the money to pay his medical expenses, he retired early at 62, with full pension, and moved to Limerick. I had my mother to support, and I was glad to have the company of my brother and sister, who also attended university. The idea of working at university was a novelty, and I quickly developed an interest in the subject I knew little about. It was not long before I had achieved a First in Modern History from the University of Dublin

Given this prompt: Interview Tips First impressions are often lasting ones. Studies show that people form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress our eye contact our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk our volume and tone of voice as well as our our actual words.
    
    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for B2 learners in the CEFR scale. 
    For your guidance, example books in this level of complexity include Moby Dick by Herman Melville, Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte, and Sense and Sensibility by Jane Austen.
    
    Output the generated story directly.
     First impressions are often lasting ones. Studies show that people form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress, how we behave, and how quickly we speak. They also tend to judge us according to how we look, our voice, our pitch and our tone.
So if your name is Joe Smith, and you are sitting for an interview for a new job, you will probably find that most interviewers will think very highly of you if they see you in a nice suit, a tie, with nice shoes, your hair combed and brushed, your teeth shiny, and a well-shaven face. They will judge you by your appearance, rather than your character and your interview is likely to be very successful if you do not make a foolish mistake.
If your name is Dan Smith, and you are sitting for an interview for a new job, the opposite may be true: most interviewers will think very poorly of you if they see you in a t-shirt and jean shorts. They will judge you by your appearance, rather than your character and your interview will likely be very unsuccessful if you do not make a foolish mistake.
But this is not the most important thing: when an employer first sees a candidate, he will be interested in what you say, but it is much more important that they find you convincing and interesting. And if this is not done, or done well, they may not consider you very highly for the job

     Hamlet was angry that he should give such a dear and respectful name as father to the murderer of his true father and he replied sharply 'Mother, you have much offended my father.' The queen asked him if he had forgotten who he was speaking to. 'Oh! I wish I could forget,' replied Hamlet. 'I wish I could. And if I could, I know a man that could teach me how.' The man was the wizard Aladdin. And with the help of Aladdin's magic lamp, he could forget anything for one day. Hamlet was very angry with this, and he said 'Oh! What a pity it is I can never forget! I shall always be haunted with the remembrance of that vile wretch! I shall never be happy as long as I am aware of his existence!' 'Alas,' answered Aladdin, 'you shall not, my lad. The lamp's magic has worn off, and you can never have it again.' 'How dreadful,' said Hamlet. 'But let us go,' he added, 'I have business to transact with my father's murderer.' 'Indeed you shall,' said Aladdin, 'though my magic lamp has now worn off and cannot give you its benefit again.' 'Why,' replied Hamlet, 'I believe I shall have the pleasure of murdering my father myself!'

Given this prompt: However most of the problems were small and most of the guests at the conference were amazed by the network. After this the ARPAnet began to grow even more rapidly. But now it was not the world's only network of computers. After the ARPAnet had shown that a computer network could be built and that it could be useful other networks began to appear.
    
    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for B2 learners in the CEFR scale. 
    For your guidance, example books in this level of complexity include Moby Dick by Herman Melville, Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte, and Sense and Sensibility by Jane Austen.

     The network was made of smaller and smaller computers. 

The first network was the ARPAnet.

The ARPAnet was made of small computers.

The ARPAnet began to grow.

But now it was not the only network of computers.

Other networks began to appear.

After the ARPAnet had shown that a computer network could be built and that it could be useful other networks began to appear.

The most common kind of network was called a local network.

The local network was made of smaller and smaller computers.

The local network began to grow.

But now it was not the only network of computers.

Other networks began to appear.

These networks were called wide-area networks (WANs).

WANs were made of computers connected by long lines.

The long lines carried data between different points within a WAN.

Some WANs were high-speed networks called optical networks.

Other WANs were high-speed networks called microwave networks.

In the early days of the Internet, the largest WAN was called the ARPANET.

ARPANET was made of computers connected by long lines.

ARPANET was the first network to show that a computer network could be built and that it could be useful.

Now other networks began to appear.

      "I haven't read the whole newspaper," my coworker answered with a smile. "But I can summarize what I did read," she laughed.

      "In the last 24 hours, I only read about my co-worker who's going to the airport, a story about my favorite band, and an article about how the weather's getting worse."

      "I'm only at work from eight until four," she replied. "After that, I try to have some time with the family and just chill."

      "I take a couple of hours to read the newspaper, but after that it's just for a couple of hours, like you said," she explained.
      "How does that affect your personal life?" I asked.

     His life had not been much of a path. 
    The world began on a grey, cold morning at the dawn of a cold winter's day. 
   Tristan Smith lay curled up in a corner of his father's one room house. 
   His mother had died a long time ago, as Tristan lay awake, crying her name. 
   Then his father's voice came calling: "Up you must get! You've slept through a great wedding party, and now we must go!" 
   Tristan felt himself drifting off in a dream, as his father led him away. 
   He didn't know what it was like to wake up on another world. 
   But for the most part, life was like the dreams he'd had as a young child. 
   There was the sunrise, and the sunset. The birds of prey. And, sometimes, the smell of a new wood. 
   He had come from a life of kings and queens. But now, as he walked to the edge of the new world, he knew that his life would be a life of humble people in the wilderness. 
   This was his world: a world of wolves.

Given this prompt: Sound the Alarm Stuart Harris reports Many of us listen to the radio when we get up in the morning and most of us also require some external means to persuade us to get out of bed. Thus we have the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one?
    
    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for C1 learners in the CEFR scale.

     We listen to radio in the morning to remind us of the alarm clock. Many of us listen to the radio when we get up in the morning and most of us also require some external means to persuade us to get out of bed. Thus we have the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one?

Stuart reports that many of us have the radio for a few hours, then turn it off. But even so, we do not have much experience of listening to radio. Thus, most of the time we are still in a daze. The problem of the daze is that we still feel sleepy at the end of the radio programme. The radio programme has not yet helped us to awake, as we require an external stimulus to get us going. Thus, although our attention has been piqued for several hours, we still require a stimulus to wake us up.

I think we need something to remind us of this, to make us wake up early. This could be a radio programme, but a good way to accomplish this is to have the programme flash in our minds. So we can remember it later. The way to make this happen is to set a timer. So that whenever we wake up, our brains are flashed with the programme. It will trigger our consciousness to wake up. We can then take the programme from memory and use it to start the day.

Given this prompt: I saw a lot of things he said. "And I know a lot more. This visit is about money. Mr. Phelan promised that he would take care of me in his will. There were many promises all broken." "Was he crazy?" "He was or he wasn't. Doesn't matter to me.

     Mr Phelan said: "I'm going to be rich! Look at me! Rich! Rich! I've got so much money I can go to the moon!"
"But no-one's ever come back from the moon. It's so far away, I'll never see it!"
"It's a fact, Mr Phelan. I'm telling you it's a fact."
"The sun doesn't set, you know," he continued. "And when you go to bed, you wake up in the morning. You don't get old. I'm young, rich, and the sun never sets."
"But it does, you know," said the other sheep. "I saw the sun set once. I went to sleep, woke up in the morning, and it was night time again. There was no sun, but it was still day."
"So what?" said Phelan. "It's no loss. I don't care if the sun doesn't set. I can get up and go to work in the morning. There's no time for the sun to set!"
"But then you've got a family," said the poor boy.
"I don't care about my family," said Phelan. "They can starve if they want to. My money's mine."
He then gave them a glass of milk from his own cow. They drank it all, then they set off to work again.

When the non-smokers made eye contact with the smoker, the smoker would often light up. They also found that the non-smokers would try to touch the smoker in places where smoking was not permitted, and that when the smokers smoked with each other, they would pass one another cigarettes to try to get the other to light up.
These results led the tobacco industry to believe that teenagers needed to be exposed to tobacco advertising in order to be convinced that they should smoke. They also realized that they should target teenagers with specific ads rather than random ones. Therefore, in the 1970s, they set out to create ads that would work for teenagers and create an impression that it was normal and cool to smoke.      A Greek-Roman Museum.
The University Museum of Classical Archaeology.
The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of cast works of ancient sculpture. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas, cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
    The Museum exhibits only the ancient sculptures from its collections. For the most part, these are from Greece and the Roman empire. The Museum also has some objects from the cultures around the Mediterranean and some ancient pottery. Most objects were brought to the Greek island of Crete by the Greeks during the Roman empire. These objects include some statues of Zeus, Zeus' mother Athena, and Hera.
    The first thing visitors should know when they enter the Museum is that these objects are not to be viewed or handled. The collections are extremely valuable. All the sculptures are of great artistic importance and are irreplaceable works of art. The Museum does not want them damaged in any way. This also includes the cast sculptures.
    After you have entered the Museum and seen all the objects, you will be directed to the special room that contains the cast sculptures. The room is dim and well-lit so you can appreciate all the works of art better. All these sculptures are on display in their original state. The only exception to that is the Zeus sculpture, which is not completely finished

Richard Cork recalls how as an 78-year-old student he came face-to-face with one of the most revered artists of the century. Even seen at a distance eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes, Picasso was instantly recognisable. I was an eight-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van.
   
    I was at an exhibition in Monaco and was invited by someone to join them at the restaurant at the end of the exhibition. There I saw for the first time, up close, one of the most respected artists of the century. When I'd taken some photos of him, he pointed to the one I'd done and said: "Don't be a fool, it's not me." I had to keep a poker face.
   
    He was extremely charming. The conversation took place, in effect, in front of all of his friends and I was in the background, looking very sad.

If anything, we're probably closer to gorillas.
That's why we do a lot of the things gorillas do.
But they've had a lot of time to develop their different features.
Like speech.
But I think that a lot of things that we do that we did over a long time—
                   —we didn't start out doing them.
       But it's quite hard to do things that we didn't start out doing
       when you're not really born with them.
    We still don't really know how we developed language.
      It may have been like the other apes, or maybe it started later.
      I think our speech developed the same way.
      We started out not really knowing how to talk properly.
     We only really learned how to talk properly.

     "Is your office working ok?" was the question asked to me by an anxious executive of a local company as she came into my office to interview me for the role of her new Human Resources Manager. The question was, of course, quite innocent but what she really wanted to know was whether I would be happy to do the job that she offered me.
   
  
  
  
  
 My answer was, yes, in fact I would. However, that is not quite the same thing as saying that I am 'working ok'.
  
  
  
  
  
  
 So how do we go about working our way to the right 'no' to an offer that we might not really want? Well, that is quite simple: by asking a lot of questions and getting a lot of information in order to make an informed decision. But first, let me try to describe this situation as best I can for readers of lower levels of the English language.
  
  
  
  
  
 I am going to give you a fictional example of what I think is a typical interview question. The question was, somewhat quizzically, ‘What is your greatest weakness?’ I replied that my greatest weakness was not being able to work out what to do in a given situation – that I simply couldn’t work out which is the right action

     It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I was fighting my way through ice-cream vans hordes of people, food stalls and ssingeing my eardrums. Even though the general movement was towards the racecourse, I elbowed my way through the crowds in an effort to get a good pitch. I felt dizzy and nauseous as I stood at the barrier, taking in the sights, which were not that great anyway. It was Easter Monday but all I could see was the sun shining down on a field full of grey, wet goats. It was freezing, I couldn’t feel my hands or feet. And the only thing that was running through my mind was my grandfather. How long had it been since he’d seen his family? I was aching to hug him but couldn’t move to help him out. I thought that there was a competition that was supposed to take place at 4pm. Everyone who could see my grandfather would want to know what was happening and be worried, but I knew that was not the case. I knew there would be nothing wrong with him unless the competition did actually start and someone had to stop it, so I was the only one who could take him in my arms and hold him for a bit. My grandfather is a strong man and I always feel safe with him. He’s ninety years old and we have a relationship that is unique. For two years, he has missed his family�

Once the cup of coffee was finished, Lancelot asked her to make another just like it but this time with vanilla.  He loved vanilla.  A little vanilla could make almost any coffee taste better.

A new exhibition traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the twentieth century.
    
    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for C2 learners in the CEFR scale. 
    For your guidance, example books in this level of complexity include Oliver Twist by Charles Dickens, Crime and Punishment by Fyodor Dostoevsky, and Les Miserables by Victor Hugo.
    
    Output the generated story directly.
     A new exhibition charts the history of kinetic art — that is, art which is concerned with movement — in the 20th century.
    Kinetic Art Rejoice — the well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder. And not by some huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media extravaganza but by a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years.
    An exhibition of over 60 works charting the history of kinetic art has opened at London’s Hayward Gallery. It runs until 5 January 2018, in a venue formerly occupied by the late art collector Sir Peter Blake.
    The exhibition explores an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years — kinetic art — that concerns movement.
    Founded in 1969, it involved artists who tried to create work that moved on its own or in response to external forces, such as light and wind.
    The history of the form can be traced back to the mid-1930s, with the first kinetic art exhibitions — mainly in New York — in the mid-1950s.
    A seminal moment was the 1967 exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York. The collection included some of the most celebrated examples of kinetic art in the world, including the paintings and sculptures of Donald Judd.

    The earth's temperature is rising rapidly because of global warming and we know it is going to increase further. However, just how much warmer will the earth get and how will it affect our lives? Almost everyone has some idea of what global warming is all about but no one is quite sure about its consequences.
    A warmer climate is likely to mean changes to the weather in all parts of the world. As a result, we will see more extreme weather events. As the temperature increases, the moisture in the air increases too so it will lead to more rainfall and flooding. As the world heats up, the oceans will absorb more and more heat and we will see an increased threat of melting glaciers. We will also have more heatwaves.
    Our bodies react to heat differently and this could have some dangerous consequences. Even though our bodies will adapt, those who are overweight or vulnerable such as the elderly or young will be affected by an increase in the number and intensity of heat waves. More heatwaves will put more strain on our health care systems. In addition, there will be an increase in air pollution as more people burn coal, oil or gas to keep warm. We could also see an increase in diseases like diabetes, asthma and heart disease.

While the arrival of home music players and MP3 players has led to a huge drop in the number of people buying vinyl discs or paying for CD subscriptions (which are now being replaced by on-line streaming services), Hallam's main point is that there has been a change in the way we listen to music.     Hallam gives some examples of this technological change, starting with the arrival of radio, which allowed listeners to tune into any of several hundred stations and skip through the'middle bits' of listening. The arrival of these new technologies in music listening led to a drop in the number of people listening to vinyl records and CD subscriptions.

     Robert took some photographs in his backyard in the summer. He decided to develop the photos using a particular darkroom method.
He had never developed any photographs before and the method that he was going to use was a new experiment in black-and-white photography. He had never done it before and he knew that it would be very expensive for him, because he had never developed any photographs.
After taking the photos, he tried them in the darkroom method and he was really impressed. But then, when he developed them with a new technique, it turned out that his photos were much better.

     Writing reviews is hard. Not everything can be done perfectly. What makes it all worth it is when you get a great review. This book is about writing great reviews by practicing what is known as the “rule of three”, which is the main principle of writing reviews. I will discuss various techniques you can use to ensure that your reviews are read, commented on, and appreciated.
I don't feel that reviews should be too long or too complex. People will rarely read these long reviews. They'll rather stop and go straight to the comments section to get more details. Keep it simple. I like it when a review has only one paragraph of information. For example, if I want to buy a new car, I would look up some reviews from the manufacturers or sites I am interested in. It would be so much easier to just read the first paragraph or two to get the overall feeling for that particular brand or model.

Write the summary, not the review.
Your summary should summarize what the reader needs to know. It's a summary, not a review.
The best way to avoid having too long a summary is to divide it into sections. In this way, you can put your best thoughts about the subject in the first and foremost section, and put the less informative part of the summary in the second one. This way, the reader will get the best of the summary, but will not be bothered by the less important parts.
